articles.headline: Scott Walker Ends His 2016 Presidential Run
articles.snippet: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin quit the race for the Republican presidential nomination and urged some of his 15 rivals to do the same in hopes of uniting the party around an alternative to Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin quit the race for the Republican presidential nomination and urged some of his 15 rivals to do the same in hopes of uniting the party around an alternative to Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, whose early glow as a Republican presidential contender was snuffed out with the rise of anti-establishment rivals, announced Monday that he was quitting the race and urged some of his 15 rivals to do the same so the party could unite against the leading candidate, Donald J. Trump.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Pope Francis to Find a Church in Upheaval
articles.snippet: Some U.S. churches are bursting with immigrant parishioners, while others struggle to stay open.
articles.abstract: Some U.S. churches are bursting with immigrant parishioners, while others struggle to stay open.
articles.lead_paragraph: MERCED, Calif. — More than 5,000 parishioners packed the pews, the choir loft and the vestibule on a recent weekend at Sacred Heart Church here in California’s Central Valley for five Masses — four of them in Spanish. Young Hispanic families spilled outside onto the steps, straining to hear the homily over the roar of an elevated freeway across the street.

articles.headline: Empty Floor at Goldman Puts Change on Display
articles.snippet: Banks have eliminated over 20 percent of the front-office head count from their Wall Street operations since 2011, according to the industry data and analytics firm Coalition.
articles.abstract: Banks have eliminated over 20 percent of the front-office head count from their Wall Street operations since 2011, according to the industry data and analytics firm Coalition.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Goldman Sachs moved into its new tower near the Hudson River in 2009, the sprawling trading desks on the fourth, fifth and sixth floors were some of the most active and lucrative in the world.

articles.headline: HBO, Longtime Emmy Favorite, Reigns Supreme
articles.snippet: New rules and openings in major categories help explain the premium cable network’s dominance as it won heavily for “Game of Thrones” and “Veep.”
articles.abstract: New rules and openings in major categories help explain the premium cable network’s dominance as it won heavily for “Game of Thrones” and “Veep.”
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Hours after the Emmy Awards ended, HBO executives, actors and writers were still busy celebrating the premium cable network’s dominance at a sweaty after-party at the Pacific Design Center.

articles.headline: The Wrath of Volkswagen’s Drivers
articles.snippet: With its admission of fraud in its diesel emissions testing, Volkswagen stands to lose drivers’ trust and the sales comeback it has sought in the United States.
articles.abstract: With its admission of fraud in its diesel emissions testing, Volkswagen stands to lose drivers’ trust and the sales comeback it has sought in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen’s stunning admission that it sold diesel-powered cars that intentionally faked emissions testing results has left many of their owners — who thought they were buying fuel-efficient and environmentally friendly vehicles — angry and feeling betrayed.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Christopher Jensen

articles.headline: Brian Williams Return Is Part of Revamp at MSNBC
articles.snippet: Brian Williams is expected to return to the air on MSNBC on Tuesday in his new role as a breaking news anchor, seven months after making some humiliating news of his own.
articles.abstract: Brian Williams is expected to return to the air on MSNBC on Tuesday in his new role as a breaking news anchor, seven months after making some humiliating news of his own.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brian Williams was eating dinner in early June at the Bronxville, N.Y., house of his new boss, Andrew Lack, discussing his fate at NBC News.

articles.headline: It Took E.P.A. Pressure to Get VW to Admit Fault
articles.snippet: Volkswagen executives told environmental regulators repeatedly that discrepancies on pollution tests were not a deliberate attempt to deceive Washington officials.
articles.abstract: Volkswagen executives told environmental regulators repeatedly that discrepancies on pollution tests were not a deliberate attempt to deceive Washington officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen executives told environmental regulators for more than a year that discrepancies between pollution tests on its diesel cars and the starkly higher levels out on the road were a technical error, not a deliberate attempt to deceive Washington officials.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Aaron M. Kessler

articles.headline: The Influence of Fiorina at Lucent, in Hindsight
articles.snippet: Carly Fiorina’s tenure as chief of Hewlett-Packard has drawn some criticism during her presidential campaign. But her career at Lucent is worth a look as well.
articles.abstract: Carly Fiorina’s tenure as chief of Hewlett-Packard has drawn some criticism during her presidential campaign. But her career at Lucent is worth a look as well.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Carly Fiorina has risen in the polls over the last week, there is renewed focus on her controversial tenure as chief executive of Hewlett-Packard. Yet her career at Lucent Technologies has been treated as little more than a footnote. It shouldn’t be.

articles.headline: As Others Flee to West, Most Syrian Refugees Remain in Region
articles.snippet: While the West grapples with thousands of Syrians, millions more have settled into lives with limited opportunities in Jordan, Turkey and Lebanon.
articles.abstract: While the West grapples with thousands of Syrians, millions more have settled into lives with limited opportunities in Jordan, Turkey and Lebanon.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZAATARI REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan — Bicycles are the new basics for the world’s largest concentration of Syrians who have fled their country’s bloody civil war. Thousands traverse this camp’s few paved roads and acres of rocky dirt, souped up with extra seats and milk crates to ferry groceries, bulky fans and small children.

articles.headline: Plan on Migrants Strains the Limits of Europe’s Unity
articles.snippet: Gathering for their second such session in eight days, the ministers haggled over a proposal to resettle an additional 120,000 people across the European Union.
articles.abstract: Gathering for their second such session in eight days, the ministers haggled over a proposal to resettle an additional 120,000 people across the European Union.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — After weeks of indecision, the European Union voted on Tuesday to distribute 120,000 asylum seekers among member states, a plan meant to display unity in the face of the largest movement of refugees on the Continent since World War II.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and James Kanter

articles.headline: Volkswagen Says 11 Million Cars Worldwide Are Affected in Diesel Deception
articles.snippet: The company did not provide information on where the affected cars are, but the overwhelming majority are probably in Europe, where the company dominates the market.
articles.abstract: The company did not provide information on where the affected cars are, but the overwhelming majority are probably in Europe, where the company dominates the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A scandal that has battered Volkswagen’s image in the United States spread to the automaker’s core market in Europe on Tuesday, when the company said that 11 million of its diesel cars were equipped with software that could be used to cheat on emissions tests. That was more than 20 times the number of cars previously disclosed.

articles.headline: IPhone 6s’s Hands-Free Siri Is an Omen of the Future
articles.snippet: Voice recognition and artificial intelligence have improved so fast that we are nearing “ambient computing,” or robotic assistants that are always on hand.
articles.abstract: Voice recognition and artificial intelligence have improved so fast that we are nearing “ambient computing,” or robotic assistants that are always on hand.
articles.lead_paragraph: The headline feature in Apple’s latest smartphones, the iPhone 6s and 6s Plus, is something called 3D Touch, which lets you activate shortcuts on the phone by pressing a bit harder on the screen. For now, though, I found a less novel, but far handier feature in the new iPhone — one that has long been the butt of jokes but is now becoming a necessary part of modern computing.

articles.headline: Lloyd Blankfein, Goldman Sachs C.E.O., Has Lymphoma
articles.snippet: Mr. Blankfein said in a letter to shareholders and employees that he had a “highly curable” form of cancer.
articles.abstract: Mr. Blankfein said in a letter to shareholders and employees that he had a “highly curable” form of cancer.
articles.lead_paragraph: It seemed to be no big deal when Gary D. Cohn, the president of Goldman Sachs, spoke at a panel event Monday night.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Health Insurance Deductibles Outpacing Wage Increases, Study Finds
articles.snippet: The costs have risen more than six times faster than workers’ earnings since 2010, Kaiser Family Foundation calculates, prompting some to forgo care.
articles.abstract: The costs have risen more than six times faster than workers’ earnings since 2010, Kaiser Family Foundation calculates, prompting some to forgo care.
articles.lead_paragraph: It may not seem like much — just an extra hundred dollars or so a year.
